content: okay guys something a little different
today relevant for terrain not necessarily for gaming a short little
story for you the holidays are coming up I wanted to do something a little
special my dad bought a motorcycle a couple years ago but something he'd
always wanted to do but I guess held off on until he and my mom were true empty
nesters because of the risk or whatever but anyway he got it he also recently
bought a couple little motorcycle models I think their Harley Davidsons they look
a lot like his they're not the same model I don't think they're even same
make but anyways he bought two of them and he asked if I could possibly repaint
them one to look like his and one of them done up in the colors of his
father's 1956 Chevy which is the classic aqua so I did that I got him painted but
that's not what the videos about I figured I would also do a little set
piece for them and here it is it's almost done I got a paint black on the
sides and everything but it's just like a highway Mountain curve really I wanted
to test out some static grass I've never used static grass before and Kickstarter
that's going on right now huge miniatures sent me some promos which I
thought would be a perfect opportunity to test out and see what the deal is
with it and also see if the Kickstarter is something worth pursuing without
further ado let's show you how I built this and I'm gonna give this to my dad
for Christmas so first I took the models and figured roughly how big in what
shape the road would be on paper then use that as a guide to cut some cork
sheeting this is the quarter inch thick stuff from the crafting store then I
trace that shape onto some one inch thick extruded polystyrene or home
insulation and I use the proxxon hot wire table to cut out four pieces now
I'm not going to belabor these in the narration you can kind of see what I'm
doing it's four pieces the top two are fairly slim they get stacked together
pinned with toothpicks temporarily and run through the hot wire to taper them
into a hill then hot glue them together the bottom two pieces are much bigger of
those two the top one has a flat area where the road will be glued on and then
it tapers off from there just like before here's a good shot where you can
see the scenes of the pieces and it should be pretty apparent how I put this
together next I did a step out of habit that really wasn't necessary at all
flocking with pebble and sand just skip it and when I have grass over it anyway
then paint this is craft smart acrylic very cheap available at Michael's or any
crafting store paint black for the road and golden brown for everything else
after that's dry a plain old Elmer's white PVA glue spread out evenly having
a brush loaded with water helped that a lot and then I just hit it the static
grass clumps when you pinch it it's a really strange feeling it's not like
flock at all it's hard to spread out and I had to
resist the temptation to sort of spread it like butter because I knew it would
create a horrible clump of glue and grass so I just kept on applying and
applying knowing that at the end I would tip it over and recover all the excess
quick dry brush of gray on the road to scuff it up then a thick bead of white
glue along its edges and dumped on some pebbles and coarse aggregate not shown a
hot glued on some clumps of moss again readily available from the crafting
store so as I've said many times before outdoor and nature stuff is not my forte
at all I'm a total amateur when it comes to like realistic terrain making so I
don't know to me static grass is like incredible I love the look of it maybe I
didn't shade it or mix it like a pro would do but I gotta say this stuff
makes me look a lot better than I really am so huge miniatures they're in their
final days of their Kickstarter and having actually used the product here my
opinion is it's definitely worth it see the video description below and Merry
Christmas dad for all you 3d printers out there don't forget to check out
Hiro's hoard where you can get true tiles models as well as a ton of other
excellent fantasy related scenery I am why lock thank you for joining me and
I'll see you next time
